February 2 – President Iskander Mirza of Pakistan lays the foundation-stone of the Guddu Barrage across the Indus River, near Sukkur.
December 4 The Lewisham rail crash in London, UK, leaves 92 people dead. Bayankhongor Earthquake in Mongolia kills 30+ people.
China's first television broadcasts start at Beijing Television Station, a predecessor of China Central Television.

February 6 – Seven Manchester United footballers are among the 21 people killed in the Munich air disaster in West Germany, on the return flight from a European Cup game in Yugoslavia. 23 people survive; manager Matt Busby and players Johnny Berry and Duncan Edwards are in a serious condition. Berry will never play again and Edwards dies a fortnight later, as does the co-pilot.
January 13 – Battle of Edchera: The Moroccan Army of Liberation ambushes a Spanish patrol.
April 13 – The Soviet satellite Sputnik 2 (launched November 3, ) disintegrates during reentry from orbit.
Charles de Gaulle is brought out of retirement at Colombey-les-Deux-Églises to lead France by decree for 6 months.

First large unit action of the Vietnam War takes place, when two companies of the ARVN's 23rd Division are ambushed by a well-organized Viet Cong force of several hundred, identified as the "2nd Liberation Battalion".
January 6 – The International Maritime Organization is inaugurated.
The southernmost island of the Maldives archipelago, Addu Atoll, declares its independence from the Kingdom of the Maldives, initiating the United Suvadive Republic.
April 27 – National People's Congress elects Liu Shaoqi as Chairman of the People's Republic of China, as a successor of Mao Zedong.
December 2 – Malpasset Dam in southern France collapses and water flows over the town of Fréjus, killing 412.

December 7 – The United Nations Security Council is called into session by the Soviet Union, in order to consider Soviet demands for the Security Council to seek the immediate release of former Congolese Premier Patrice Lumumba.

The State of Somaliland (the former British Somaliland protectorate) receives its independence from the United Kingdom. Five days later, it unites as scheduled with the Trust Territory of Somalia (the former Italian Somaliland), to form the Somali Republic.
The countries of El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua announce the formation of the Central American Common Market.
August 29 – Hurricane Donna kills 50 people in Florida and New England.
The Canton of Geneva in Switzerland gives women the right to vote.

Australian federal election: Robert Menzies' Liberal/Country Coalition Government is re-elected with a one-seat majority, narrowly defeating the Labor Party led by Arthur Calwell. One of the closest election results in Australian history, such a result will not be replicated again until.
February 1 – The United States tests its first Minuteman I intercontinental ballistic missile.
Kurenivka mudslide: A dam bursts in Kiev, USSR, killing 145.
May 15 – J. Heinrich Matthaei alone performs the Poly-U-Experiment, and is the first person to recognize and understand the genetic code.
November 18 – U.S. President John F.
November 29 – An agreement is signed between Britain and France, to develop the Concorde supersonic airliner.
February 20 – Project Mercury: Aboard Friendship 7, John Glenn becomes the first American to orbit the Earth, three times in 4 hours, 55 minutes.
Luisenthal Mine Disaster: A coal mine explosion in Saarland, West Germany kills 299.
November 2 – Greville Wynne, a British trader acting as a courier for MI6, is arrested by the KGB in Budapest and imprisoned in Moscow after confessing to espionage.
The Helsinki Convention on Nordic Co-operation of March 23 comes into force in the Nordic countries.
Tsurumi rail accident: A triple train disaster in Yokohama kills 161.

November 23 The Golden Age Nursing Home fire kills 63 elderly people near Fitchville, Ohio, United States. The long-running sci-fi television series Doctor Who premieres on BBC TV in the United Kingdom.

Trans-Canada Air Lines Flight 831, a Douglas DC-8 crashes into a wooded hillside after taking-off from Dorval International Airport near Montreal, killing all 118 on board, the worst air disaster for many years in Canada's history.
November 2 – South Vietnamese coup: Arrest and assassination of Ngo Dinh Diem, the South Vietnamese President.
December 20 – The Frankfurt Auschwitz Trials begin.
November 21 Second Vatican Council: The third period of the Catholic Church's ecumenical council closes. Lumen gentium, the Dogmatic Constitution on the Church, is promulgated.
October 26 – Eric Edgar Cooke becomes the last man executed in Western Australia, for murdering 8 citizens in Perth between and.

January 9 – Martyrs' Day: Armed clashes between United States troops and Panamanian civilians in the Panama Canal Zone precipitate a major international crisis, resulting in the deaths of 21 Panamanians and 4 U.S. soldiers.

February 5 – India backs out of its promise to hold a plebiscite in the disputed territory of Kashmir. In, India had taken the issue of Kashmir to the United Nations Security Council and offered to hold a plebiscite in the held Kashmir under UN supervision.
November 24 – Belgian paratroopers and mercenaries capture Stanleyville, but a number of hostages die in the fighting, among them American Evangelical Covenant Church missionary Paul Carlson.
Suat Hayri Ürgüplü forms the new government of Turkey (29th government).
Fighting resumes between Indian and Pakistani troops.
November 28 – Vietnam War: In response to U.S. President Lyndon B.
U.S. troops occupy the Dominican Republic.

British theatre critic Kenneth Tynan says "fuck" during a discussion on BBC satirical programme BBC-3 for what many believed was the first time on British television. The corporation later issues a public apology.

November 26 Australian federal election: Harold Holt's Liberal/Country Coalition government is re-elected with a significantly increased majority, defeating the Labor Party led by Arthur Calwell. Calwell resigns as Labor leader shortly after; he will be replaced by his deputy and future Prime Minister Gough Whitlam.
August 19 – The 6.8 Mw Varto earthquake affects the town of Varto in eastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX, killing at least 2,394–3,000 and injuring at least 1,420.
Joseph Weizenbaum created ELIZA, the first chatbot.
Indonesia and Malaysia issue a joint peace declaration, formally ending the Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation which began in.
The British Labour Party led by Harold Wilson wins the United Kingdom general election, gaining a 96-seat majority (compared with a single seat majority when the election was called on February 28).
April 24 – Soyuz 1: Vladimir Komarov becomes the first Soviet cosmonaut to die, when the parachute of his space capsule fails during re-entry.
August 10 – Belgian mercenary Jean Schramme's troops take the Congolese border town of Bukavu.

October 18 Vietnam War: Students at the University of Wisconsin–Madison protest over recruitment by Dow Chemical on the university campus; 76 are injured in the resulting riot. Walt Disney's 19th full-length animated feature The Jungle Book, the last animated film personally supervised by Disney, is released and becomes an enormous box-office and critical success.
April 9 – The first Boeing 737 (A-100 series) takes its maiden flight.
U.S. Senator Eugene McCarthy announces his candidacy for the Democratic Party presidential nomination, challenging incumbent President Lyndon B.

March 19–23 – Afrocentrism, Black Power, Vietnam War: Students at Howard University in Washington, D.C., signal a new era of militant student activism on college campuses in the U.S. Students stage rallies, protests and a 5-day sit-in, laying siege to the administration building, shutting down the university in protest over its ROTC program and the Vietnam War, and demanding a more Afrocentric curriculum.

September 17 – The D'Oliveira affair: The Marylebone Cricket Club tour of South Africa is cancelled when the South Africans refuse to accept the presence of Basil D'Oliveira, a Cape Coloured, in the England side.
June 12 – The horror film Rosemary's Baby premieres in the U.S.
September 29 – A referendum in Greece gives more power to the military junta.
June 5 – Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy: Senator Robert F.
Apollo program: Apollo 12 astronauts Charles Conrad and Alan Bean land at Oceanus Procellarum ("Ocean of Storms"), becoming the third and fourth humans to walk on the Moon.
February 24 – The Mariner 6 Mars probe is launched from the United States.
September 1 Libyan coup d'état: A bloodless coup in Libya ousts King Idris and brings Colonel Muammar Gaddafi to power. For Brazil, the Jornal Nacional was created on Monday, 1 September.
December 12 – The Piazza Fontana bombing in Milan, Italy, kills 17 people and injures 88.
The Act of Free Choice for West Irian commences in Merauke, Indonesia.
September 20 Syrian armored forces cross the Jordanian border. Luna 16 lands on the Moon and lifts off the next day with samples, landing back on Earth September 24.

November 1 The Club Cinq-Sept fire in Saint-Laurent-du-Pont, France, kills 146. Polish Deputy Foreign Minister Zygfryd Wolniak and three Pakistanis are killed in an attack on a group of Polish diplomats at the Karachi airport.
June 4 – Tonga gains independence from the United Kingdom.
June 1 – Soyuz 9, a two-man spacecraft, is launched from the Soviet Union for an orbital flight of nearly 18 days, an endurance record at this time.
Luna 16 lands on the Moon and lifts off the next day with samples, landing back on Earth September 24.
July 14 – Libya severs its diplomatic ties with Morocco.
June 28 – Assassin Jerome A. Johnson shoots Joe Colombo, boss of his eponymous crime family, in the head during an Italian-American rally, putting him in a coma.
Austria and the People's Republic of China establish diplomatic relations.
The world's largest hydroelectric plant in Krasnoyarsk, Soviet Union, begins operations.
A South Korean marine kills 6 people in a mass shooting in Kimpo, South Korea.
February 26 – Luna 20 comes back to Earth with 55 grams (1.9 ounces) of lunar soil.
August 14 – An East German Ilyushin airliner crashes near East Berlin; all 156 on board perish.

April 13 – The Universal Postal Union decides to recognize the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate Chinese representative, effectively expelling the Republic of China administering Taiwan.
Libya and the Soviet Union sign a cooperation treaty.
March 4 Libya and the Soviet Union sign a cooperation treaty. The Organisation of the Islamic Conference Charter is signed (effective February 28, ).
Value Added Tax is introduced in the United Kingdom.
May 14 – Skylab, the United States' first space station, is launched.
Billie Jean King beats Bobby Riggs in a singles tennis match billed as the "Battle of the Sexes".
June 26 – At Plesetsk Cosmodrome, nine people are killed in the explosion of a Cosmos 3-M rocket.
Mars 6, also known as 3MP No. 50P, is launched by the Soviet Union to explore Mars.

November 17 – The Greek legislative election, the first election since the fall of the Greek junta of –, is held and the newly formed New Democracy party wins 220 of 300 seats in the Hellenic Parliament.
July 15 – The Greek military junta sponsors a coup d'état in Cyprus, replacing President Makarios III with Nikos Sampson.
African Youth Amílcar Cabral is founded in Guinea-Bissau.
November 22 – The United Nations General Assembly grants the Palestine Liberation Organization observer status.
November 26 – Anneline Kriel is crowned as Miss World, the second South African to hold the title after Penny Coelen in, when Helen Morgan resigns four days after winning the 24th Miss World pageant.

December 13 Australian federal election: The Liberal/National Country Coalition led by Malcolm Fraser defeats the recently dismissed Labor government led by Gough Whitlam. The Fraser government achieves what is so far the largest parliamentary majority in federal Australian political history.

July 17 – Apollo–Soyuz Test Project: A crewed American Apollo spacecraft and the crewed Soviet Soyuz spacecraft for the Soyuz 19 mission dock in orbit, marking the first such link-up between spacecraft from the 2 nations.
September 16 Papua New Guinea gains its independence from Australia. Cape Verde, Mozambique and São Tomé and Príncipe join the United Nations.

Some members of Jehovah's Witnesses believe that Armageddon will occur this year based on the group's chronology and some sell their houses and businesses to prepare for the new world paradise which they believe will be created when Jesus establishes God's Kingdom on Earth.
May 28 – Fifteen West African countries sign the Treaty of Lagos, creating the Economic Community of West African States.
August 7 – Viking program: Viking 2 enters into orbit around Mars.
The Summer Olympics ends in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
December 1 Angola joins the United Nations. José López Portillo takes office as President of Mexico.
The great heat wave in the United Kingdom, which is currently suffering from drought conditions, reaches its peak.
October 26 – Transkei gains "independence" from South Africa.
May 27 The Aeroflot Ilyushin 62 airplane crash in Cuba kills 69 people. A demonstration and coup attempt in Angola takes place.
May 17 – The Likud Party, led by Menachem Begin, wins the national elections in Israel.

The Big Ear, a radio telescope operated by Ohio State University as part of the SETI project, receives a radio signal from deep space; the event is named the Wow! signal for a notation made by a volunteer on the project.
Egyptian President Anwar Sadat becomes the first Arab leader to make an official visit to Israel, when he meets with Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin, seeking a permanent peace settlement.

November 19 Egyptian President Anwar Sadat becomes the first Arab leader to make an official visit to Israel, when he meets with Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin, seeking a permanent peace settlement. TAP Portugal Flight 425 crashes at Madeira Airport, Funchal, Portugal, killing 131 and leaving 33 survivors.
September 20 – General Rahimuddin Khan assumes the post of martial law Governor of Balochistan.
June 2 – Japan Air Lines 115 had its tail struck on the runway on the airport it landed in. The same aircraft would be involved in a 2nd accident 7 years later.
May 20 – Mavis Hutchinson, 53, becomes the first woman to run across the U.S.; her trek took 69 days.
July 3 – The Amazon Co-operation Treaty is signed.
Soviet dissident Yuri Orlov is sentenced to 7 years' hard labor, for distributing 'counterrevolutionary material'.
Milk and Honey win the Eurovision Song Contest for Israel, with the song Hallelujah.
June 25 – NATO Supreme Allied Commander Alexander Haig escapes an assassination attempt in Belgium by the Baader-Meinhof terrorist organization.

In, the United States officially severed diplomatic ties with the Republic of China. This decision marked a significant shift in U.S. foreign policy, turning to view the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate representative of China.

December 3 The Who concert disaster: Eleven fans are killed during a crowd crush for unreserved seats before The Who rock concert at the Riverfront Coliseum in Cincinnati. The United States dollar exchange rate with the Deutsche Mark falls to 1.7079 DM, the all-time low so far; this record is not broken until November 5,.

February 13 An intense windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a 1.3 km (0.81 mi) long section of the Hood Canal Bridge. The Guardian Angels are formed in New York City as an unarmed organization of young crime fighters.
February 25 – A coup in Suriname ousts the government of Henck Arron; leaders Dési Bouterse and Roy Horb replace it with a National Military Council.
May 18 – The eruption of Mount St. Helens volcano in Washington kills 57 and causes US$3 billion in damage.
June 3 – Grand Island tornado outbreak: A series of deadly tornadoes strikes Grand Island, Nebraska, causing over $300m in damage, killing five people and injuring over 250.

November 10–12 – Voyager program: The NASA space probe Voyager I makes its closest approach to Saturn, when it flies within 77,000 miles (124,000 km) of the planet's cloud-tops and sends the first high-resolution images of the world back to scientists on Earth.
April 25 – Dan-Air Flight 1008 crashes in Tenerife, killing all 146 occupants; at the time it was the worst air disaster involving a British-registered aircraft in terms of loss of life.
June 6 – Bihar train disaster: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train fall off the tracks into the Bagmati River in Bihar, India, killing between 500 and 800.
The Boeing 767 airliner makes its first flight.
July 1 – Wonderland murders: The Wonderland Gang of cocaine dealers is brutally murdered in Los Angeles. Eddie Nash is suspected of involvement, but will never be convicted.
December 7 – Rotary International charters the Rotary Club of Grand Baie, Mauritius.
January to March – Heavy snow causes several houses and buildings to collapse in northwestern Japan; 152 are killed.
May 21 Falklands War: HMS Ardent is sunk by Argentine aircraft, killing 22 sailors. The International Maritime Organization is established.
December 26 – Time magazine's Man of the Year is given, for the first time to a non-human, the computer.
April 30 – The Bijon Setu massacre takes place in broad daylight at a railway crossing in India.
September 29 – Chicago Tylenol murders: an unknown killer laces Tylenol capsules with potassium cyanide that kills seven in Chicago, Illinois.
March 10 The United States places an embargo on Libyan oil imports, alleging Libyan state-sponsored terrorism. Syzygy: All 9 planets recognized at this time align on the same side of the Sun.
November 3 – Commencement of the battle of Tripoli between Arafat loyalists and PLO dissidents.
Hurricane Alicia hits the Texas coast, killing 22 and causing over US$3.8 billion in damage.

February 3 – Prime Minister of Australia Malcolm Fraser is granted a double dissolution of both houses of parliament, for elections on March 5,. As Fraser is being granted the dissolution, Bill Hayden resigns as leader of the Australian Labor Party, and in the subsequent leadership spill Bob Hawke is elected as Hayden's successor unopposed.
June 18–19 – The team of Vern Schuppan, Al Holbert and Hurley Haywood wins the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
August 4 Thomas Sankara becomes President of Upper Volta. Bettino Craxi is sworn in as Italy's first prime minister from the Italian Socialist Party.
August 4 The African republic Upper Volta changes its name to Burkina Faso. Soviet submarine K-278 Komsomolets reaches a record submergence depth of 1,020 meters.
April 12 – Palestinian gunmen take Israeli bus number 300 hostage. Israeli special forces storm the bus, freeing the hostages (one hostage, two hijackers killed).

March 12 – The National Union of Mineworkers strikes as tens of thousands of miners in the United Kingdom stop working in protest over colliery closures, starting the United Kingdom miners' strike that lasts a year.
February 8–19 – The Winter Olympics are held in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

November 6 – United States presidential election: Republican President Ronald Reagan defeats Democratic former Vice President Walter F. Mondale with 59% of the popular vote, the highest since Richard Nixon's 61% popular vote victory in.
July 20 – State President of South Africa, P. W.
April 23 – Coca-Cola changes its formula and releases New Coke. The response is overwhelmingly negative and the original formula is back on the market in less than three months.
October 3 – The Space Shuttle Atlantis makes its maiden flight.
February 14 – Lebanon hostage crisis: CNN reporter Jeremy Levin is freed from captivity in Lebanon.
May 16 – Scientists of the British Antarctic Survey announce the discovery of the ozone hole.
March 1 – Olof Palme's deputy Ingvar Carlsson becomes acting Prime Minister of Sweden. He is elected Prime Minister by the Swedish Riksdag on March 15.
The Soviet Union launches the Mir space station.
December 23 – Rutan Voyager completes the first nonstop circumnavigation of the earth by air without refueling in 9 days, 3 minutes and 44 seconds.
29 people are killed in the Pozzetto massacre.
June 14 – Fantasyland's Mindbender derails and kills three people.
Mass Rapid Transit system in Singapore opens for passenger service.
November 18 The King's Cross fire on the London Underground kills 31 people and injures a further 100. Iran–Contra affair: U.S.
December 30 – Pope John Paul II issues the encyclical Sollicitudo rei socialis (On Social Concern).

June 19 Teddy Seymour is officially designated the first black man to sail around the world, when he completes his solo sailing circumnavigation in Frederiksted, St. Croix, of the United States Virgin Islands. Edwards v.
The U.S. Department of Education announces new guidelines for teaching about AIDS in public schools, emphasizing the importance of abstinence and "appropriate moral and social conduct.".
April 18 – The United States Navy retaliates for the USS Samuel B. Roberts mining with Operation Praying Mantis, in a day of strikes against Iranian oil platforms and naval vessels.

January 7–8 – In the Soviet-Afghan War, 39 men of the Soviet Airborne Troops from the 345th Independent Guards Airborne Regiment fight off an attack by 200 to 250 Mujahideen in the Battle for Hill 3234, later dramatized in the Russian film The 9th Company.
A Colombian Boeing 727 jetliner, Avianca Flight 410, crashes into the side of the mountains near the Venezuelan border, killing 143 people.
Oshakati bomb blast: A bomb explodes outside the First National Bank in Oshakati, Namibia, killing 27 and injuring 70.
April 5 – Kuwait Airways Flight 422 is hijacked while en route from Bangkok, Thailand, to Kuwait. The hijackers demand the release of 17 Shiite Muslim prisoners held by Kuwait.
July 18 – Actress Rebecca Schaeffer is murdered by an obsessed fan, leading to stricter stalking laws in California.
David Dinkins becomes the first African-American mayor of New York City.
The Satanic Verses controversy: Iran places a $3,000,000 bounty on the head of The Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie.

November 15 Lech Wałęsa, leader of Poland's Solidarity movement, addresses a Joint session of the United States Congress. Brazil holds the first round of its first free election in 29 years; Fernando Collor de Mello and Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva advance to the second round, to be held the following month.
In the Republic of China legislative election, the Kuomintang suffers its worst election setback in forty years, winning only 53% of the popular vote.
May 2 – In London, a man brandishing a knife robs a courier of bearer bonds worth £292 million (the second largest mugging to date).
April 25 – Violeta Chamorro is sworn in as President of Nicaragua, the first woman elected (February 25) in her own right as a head of state in the Americas.
February 28 – President of Nicaragua Daniel Ortega announces a cease-fire with the U.S.-backed contras.

Provisional Irish Republican Army assassination attempt on the life of Air Chief Marshal Sir Peter Terry at his home near Stafford, England. Hit by at least 9 bullets, the former Governor of Gibraltar survives, as does his wife, Lady Betty Terry, who is also shot (most likely by accident).
McMartin preschool trial: Peggy McMartin Buckey and Raymond Buckey are acquitted of 52 charges related to alleged ritual abuse taking place at their daycare in Manhattan Beach.

March 15 Germany formally regains complete independence after the four post-World War II occupying powers (France, the U.K., the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.) relinquish all remaining rights to the country. The U.S. and Albania resume diplomatic relations for the first time since.
November 20 – An Azerbaijani Mil Mi-8 helicopter carrying a 19-member peacekeeping mission team is shot down by Armenian military forces in Khojavend District, Azerbaijan.
End of Apartheid: The South African parliament repeals the Population Registration Act, which has required racial classification of all South Africans at birth.
March 10 – Salvadoran Civil War: In the Salvadoran legislative election, the Nationalist Republican Alliance wins 39 of the 48 seats in the legislative assembly.

November 5 Tropical Storm Thelma causes flash floods in the Philippine city of Ormoc, killing more than 4,900 people. China and Vietnam restore diplomatic relations after a 13-year rift which followed the Sino-Vietnamese War.
A jury in Miami, Florida, convicts former Panamanian ruler Manuel Noriega of assisting Colombia's cocaine cartel.

December 12 – The 7.8 Mw Flores earthquake affects the Lesser Sunda Islands in Indonesia with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII leaving at least 2,500 dead. A destructive tsunami with wave heights of 25 m (82 ft) follows.
January 26 Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia will stop targeting cities of the United States and its allies with nuclear weapons. In return President George H.
April 7 – The United States recognizes the independence of Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The European Communities also recognizes Bosnia and Herzegovina.
July 16 – At the Democratic National Convention, Arkansas Governor Bill Clinton accepts his party's presidential nomination on behalf of the "forgotten middle class".
Eritreans vote overwhelmingly for independence from Ethiopia in a United Nations-monitored referendum, the Eritrean independence referendum.
August 13 – More than 130 die in the collapse of Royal Plaza Hotel at Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand's worst hotel disaster.
October 11–28 – The UNMIH is prevented from entering Haiti by its military-led regime. On October 18, United Nations economic sanctions (abolished in August) are reinstated.
Attack on Pakistani military in Somalia: twenty-four Pakistani troops in the United Nations forces are killed in Mogadishu, Somalia.
The World Health Organization declares tuberculosis a global emergency.
July 4 – Rwandan Patriotic Front troops capture Kigali, a major breakthrough in the Rwandan Civil War.
November 20 – The Angolan government and UNITA rebels sign the Lusaka Protocol.
February 24 – In Gloucester, England, local police begin excavations at 25 Cromwell Street, the home of Fred West, a suspect in multiple murders. On February 28, he and his wife are arrested.

July 25 – Israel and Jordan sign the Washington Declaration as a preliminary to signature on October 25 of the Israel–Jordan peace treaty, which formally ends the state of war that has existed between the nations since.
November 28 – Voters in Norway decide not to join the European Union in a referendum.
November 30 – Operation Desert Storm officially ends.
Final The Far Side comic by Gary Larson is published.
NATO begins peacekeeping in Bosnia.

May 17 – San Diego tank rampage: In San Diego, Shawn Nelson steals an M60A3 tank from a local California Army National Guard armory and goes on a rampage for 25 minutes, damaging over $149,201 of property. The rampage ended when San Diego police forced the hatch open and fatally shot him.
September 26 – The trial against former Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who is accused of Mafia connections, begins.
The first three-parent baby is conceived in New Jersey through mitochondrial donation.

June 11 An explosion in a São Paulo suburban shopping centre kills 44 people and injures more than 100. A peace convoy carrying Chechen separatist leaders and international diplomats is targeted by a series of remotely controlled land mines; eight people are killed.
German orthography reform of agreed internationally.
December 9 – Jerry Rawlings is re-elected as President of Ghana.
August 6 – NASA announces that the Allan Hills 84001 meteorite, thought to originate from Mars, may contain evidence of primitive lifeforms; further tests are inconclusive.

Turkish military memorandum: As a result of a meeting held by the National Security Council, the Turkish Armed Forces issues a memorandum to adopt more secular criteria. Later on June 18, the Turkish government resigns because of the pressure.
In Cambodia, Hun Sen of the Cambodian People's Party overthrows Norodom Ranariddh in a coup.

October 15 Andy Green sets the first supersonic land speed record for the ThrustSSC team, led by Richard Noble of the UK. ThrustSSC goes through the flying mile course at Black Rock Desert, Nevada at an average speed of 1,227.985 km/h (763.035 mph).
Over 98 (and possibly up to 400) are killed in the Rais massacre in Algeria.
March 18 – The tail of a Russian An-24 charter plane breaks off while en route to Turkey, causing the plane to crash, killing all 50 on board, and resulting in the grounding of all An-24s.

May 28 – Nuclear testing: In response to a series of Indian nuclear tests, Pakistan explodes five nuclear devices of its own in the Chagai hills of Baluchistan, codenamed Chagai-I, prompting the United States, Japan and other nations to impose economic sanctions. Pakistan celebrates Youm-e-Takbir annually.
October 3 – Australian federal election: John Howard's Liberal/National Coalition government is re-elected with a substantially reduced majority, defeating the Labor Party led by Kim Beazley.

September 4 – Google, Inc. is founded in Menlo Park, California, by Stanford University PhD candidates Larry Page and Sergey Brin. Jean Kambanda is sentenced to life in prison for his role in the Rwandan genocide.
February 7–22 – The Winter Olympics are held in Nagano, Japan.

October 10 – Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet: General Augusto Pinochet, Chilean dictator from to, is indicted for human rights violations he committed in Chile by Spanish magistrate Baltasar Garzón. 6 days later British police place him under house arrest during his medical treatment in the UK. This is a leading case in the law of universal jurisdiction.
December 26 – Cyclone Lothar kills 140 people as it crosses France, southern Germany, and Switzerland.
March 12 – Former Warsaw Pact members Hungary, Poland, and the Czech Republic join NATO.
October 5 – Thirty-one people die in the Ladbroke Grove rail crash, west of London, England.
October 27 – Armenian parliament shooting: Gunmen open fire in the Armenian Parliament, killing Prime Minister Vazgen Sargsyan, Parliament Chairman Karen Demirchyan, and six other members.

The Catholic Church and several Lutheran Church leaders sign the Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification, attempting to resolve a centuries-old doctrinal dispute over the nature of faith and salvation.
July 7 – The draft assembly of Human Genome Project is announced at the White House by US President Bill Clinton, Francis Collins, and Craig Venter.
Six Nations Championship in rugby union opens, the first year in which Italy takes part.
November 12 – The United States recognizes the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

August 12 – The Russian submarine Kursk sinks in the Barents Sea during one of the largest Russian naval exercises since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, resulting in the deaths of all 118 men on board.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 11,722.98 (at the peak of the Dot-com bubble).
– 1895 : "Harvest scene", tempera facsimile by Nina de Garis Davies of wall painting in the tomb of Khnumhotep II, Beni Hasan. Twelfth Dynasty.
The Harappa Torso was sculpted by a member of the Indus Valley culture.
: Farmers and herders traveled south from modern-day Ethiopia and settled in what is now Kenya. Dawn of the Capacha Culture in modern-day Colima, Mexico.
Humans settle in Matanchén, modern day Nayarit, Mexico.
Dawn of the Capacha Culture in modern-day Colima, Mexico.
February 6 – Israeli prime ministerial election: Ariel Sharon of the Likud party is elected Prime Minister of Israel.
December 15 – The Leaning Tower of Pisa is reopened to the public after 12 years of reconstruction.
October 17 – Assassination of Rehavam Ze'evi: Israeli tourism minister Rehavam Ze'evi is assassinated by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

Vejce ambush: Eight Macedonian soldiers are killed in an ambush by the NLA near Vejce, a village in the Šar Mountains, Macedonia. It represents the heaviest death toll for the government forces in a single incident during the insurgency.
The Genesis probe is launched from Cape Canaveral Space Launch Complex 17.
February 23 The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia kidnap the presidential candidate Íngrid Betancourt, holding her captive for the next six years. A ceasefire ends Eelam War III in Sri Lanka.
February 6 – Queen Elizabeth II of the Commonwealth realms celebrates her Golden Jubilee, marking 50 years since her accession to the thrones of the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

January 6 – The Boston Globe publishes results of an investigation leading to the criminal prosecutions of five Roman Catholic priests and bringing widespread attention to the sexual abuse of minors by Catholic clergy.
Hindu Kush earthquakes: A 6.1 magnitude earthquake strikes Nahrin, Afghanistan, killing 800 people and leaving 10,000 homeless.

December 17 A peace agreement is made in the Second Congo War, approving the creation of the Transitional Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The International Court of Justice rules in favor of Malaysia in the Ligitan and Sipadan dispute with Indonesia.
August 15 – Libya formally accepts civil responsibility for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in.
October 24 – Concorde makes its last commercial flight, bringing the era of airliner supersonic travel to an end.
September 26 – The 8.3 Mw Tokachi earthquake occurs off the coast of Hokkaido.
July 28 – The Tasman Spirit oil spill occurs in Pakistan.
March 31 – In its first military operation, the European Union takes over peacekeeping operations in Macedonia from NATO's Operation Allied Harmony.

June 21 In Mojave, California, United States, SpaceShipOne becomes the first privately funded spaceplane to achieve spaceflight. - municipal reorganization of Montreal: Quebec voters pass a referendum to reverse the Montreal "Mega-City" consolidation.
December 31 – Taipei 101, at the time the tallest skyscraper in the world, standing at a height of 1,670 feet (510 m), officially opens.
September 22 – West Sulawesi is established as the 33rd province of Indonesia.
December 23 – The Second Battle of Fallujah ends.

May 15 - Arsenal F.c. defeat Leicester City F.c. 2 - 1 at Highbury Stadium on the last day of the –04 FA Premier League to end the season unbeaten, the first and, so far, only time a team in the Premier League has done so. The team would go on to be known throughout the world as The Invincibles (English football).
July 23 – A series of bombings hit the resort city of Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, killing over 80 people.
October 17 – The final eclipse of was a partial lunar eclipse event, occurring at ascending node in Aries. This was 2.9 days after the Moon reached perigee.
September 30 – Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten, sparking outrage and violent riots by Muslims around the world.
April 23 – The first ever YouTube video is uploaded, titled Me at the zoo.
Microsoft releases the Xbox 360.
October 9 North Korea claims to have conducted its first-ever nuclear test. Google purchased YouTube for US$1.65 billion.
June 9 to July 9 – The FIFA World Cup takes place in Germany; Italy defeats France in the final.
September 4 — Australian conservationist Steve Irwin is fatally stung in the heart by a stingray while filming an underwater documentary.
December 24 – Ethiopia admits its troops have intervened in Somalia.
The United States Armed Forces withdraws its forces in Iceland, thereby disbanding the Iceland Defense Force.
March 27 – Latvian Prime Minister Aigars Kalvītis and Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Fradkov sign a border treaty between Latvia and Russia, officially demarcating the border between the two.

May 4 – The Greensburg tornado moves through Kiowa County, Kansas, United States, striking the town of Greensburg and killing eleven residents. 95% of the town was destroyed, and the tornado was the first to be rated EF5 on the Enhanced Fujita scale.

December 27 Former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto is assassinated, along with 20 other people, at an election rally in Rawalpindi. Riots erupt in Mombasa, Kenya, after Mwai Kibaki is declared the winner of the general election, triggering a political, economic, and humanitarian crisis that killed over 1,000 people.
October 10 – Valve Software releases The Orange Box on Windows and Xbox 360.

December 1 – At the age of 81 years, 244 days, Queen Elizabeth II becomes the oldest ever reigning British monarch, surpassing Queen Victoria who was aged 81 years, 243 days upon her death on January 22, 1901.
An earthquake measuring 7.9 on the moment magnitude scale strikes Sichuan, China, killing an estimated 87,000 people.
October 22 – The Indian Space Research Organisation successfully launches the Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft on a lunar exploration mission.

December 22 – An ash dike ruptured at a solid waste containment area for a Tennessee Valley Authority coal-fired power plant in Roane County, Tennessee, releasing 4.2 million m (1.1 billion US gal) of coal fly ash slurry in the largest industrial spill in U.S. history.

September 10 – The proton beam is circulated for the first time in the Large Hadron Collider, the world's largest and highest-energy particle accelerator, located at CERN, near Geneva, under the Franco-Swiss border.
The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope is launched.

June 25 – The death of American pop star Michael Jackson triggers an outpouring of worldwide grief. Online, reactions to the event cripple several major websites and services, as the abundance of people accessing the web addresses pushes internet traffic to unprecedented and historic levels.
August 3 – Bolivia becomes the first South American country to declare the right of indigenous people to govern themselves.
The album Breakdown is released by American rock band Green Day, which sold over 5 million copies.

August 1 – Former President of the Philippines Corazon Aquino dies at the age of 76 of cardiopulmonary arrest after complications of colon cancer. A memorial service and funeral is scheduled for August 5. (Philippine Daily Inquirer).
June 11 – The outbreak of the H1N1 influenza strain, commonly referred to as "swine flu", is deemed a global pandemic.
August 21 – Australian federal election: Julia Gillard's Labor government is re-elected, narrowly defeating the Liberal/National Coalition led by Tony Abbott.

October 26 – Repeated eruptions of Mount Merapi volcano in Central Java, Indonesia, and accompanying pyroclastic flows of scalding gas, pumice, and volcanic ash descending the erupting volcano kill 353 people and force hundreds of thousands of residents to evacuate.
July 8 – The first 24-hour flight by a solar-powered plane is completed by the Solar Impulse.

November 29 – The European Union agree to an €85 billion rescue deal for Ireland from the European Financial Stability Facility, the International Monetary Fund and bilateral loans from the United Kingdom, Denmark and Sweden.
January 10 – Religious violence erupts in Jos, Nigeria, which left scores dead, and many injured.
January 5 – Internet vigilante group Anonymous launches DoS attacks on Syrian, Tunisian, Bahraini, Egyptian, Libyan, and Jordanian government websites in response to the Arab Spring protests.

July 20 Goran Hadžić is detained in Serbia, becoming the last of 161 people indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. The United Nations declares a famine in southern Somalia, the first in over 30 years.
UNESCO admits Palestine as a member, following a vote which 107 member states support and 14 oppose.
December 19 – Liechtenstein becomes the 26th member state of the Schengen Area.
May 22 – The Joplin tornado, an EF5 tornado, strikes Joplin, Missouri, killing 158 people and injuring 1,150.
June 24 – Lonesome George, the last known individual of the Pinta Island tortoise subspecies, dies in Galápagos National Park, thus making the subspecies extinct.

December 21 The music video for Psy's Gangnam Style becomes the first YouTube video to reach a billion views. phenomenon: End of 13th b'ak'tun in the Mayan calendar, supposed end of the world according to new age beliefs. Festivities took place to commemorate the event in the countries that were part of the Maya civilization (Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador), with main events at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala.
July 30–31 – In the worst power outage in world history, the India blackouts leave 620 million people without power.

October 22 – November 2 – Hurricane Sandy, the largest Atlantic hurricane on record (as measured by diameter, with tropical-storm-force winds spanning 900 miles (1,400 km)), wreaks havoc, resulting in 233 total deaths and $68.7 billion damage.

September 11–27 – A series of terrorist attacks are directed against United States diplomatic missions worldwide, as well as diplomatic missions of Germany, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In the US, opinions are divided over whether the attacks are a reaction to a YouTube trailer for the film Innocence of Muslims.
November 8 – Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest tropical cyclones on record, hits the Philippines and Vietnam, causing devastation with at least 6,241 people dead.
January 11 – The French military begins a 5-month intervention into the Northern Mali conflict, targeting the militant Islamist Ansar Dine group.
September 8 – The Colorado floods begin, resulting from heavy rain in the Colorado River Basin.
August 15 – Horacio Cartes is sworn in as President of Paraguay.
September 7 Australian federal election: The Liberal/National Coalition led by Tony Abbott defeats the Labor Government led by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd. Abbott is sworn in on September 18.
July 23–August 3 – The Commonwealth Games takes place in Glasgow, Scotland.

October 24 – Alan Eustace, an American computer scientist, sets a world record highest and longest free fall jump from 135,908 feet (41.425 km) over Roswell, New Mexico, United States, breaking the sound barrier without any machine assistance during a record space dive out of a massive helium-filled balloon. His descent to Earth lasts 4 minutes 27 seconds and stretches nearly 26 miles (42 km) with peak speeds exceeding 822 miles per hour (1,323 km/h), setting new world records for the highest free-fall jump and total free-fall distance 123,414 feet (37,617 m).
The World Health Organization identifies the spread of poliomyelitis in at least 10 countries as a major worldwide health emergency.
December 31 – A stampede occurred on New Year's Eve in Shanghai, China, resulting in the deaths of 36 people and leaving 49 injured.
The fifth ICC T20 World Cup in cricket is held in Bangladesh.

August 12 and 15 – Large explosions in Tianjin, China kill 173 and injure more than 800 people. The causes of the explosions were found to be an overheated container of dry nitrocellulose and around 800 tonnes of ammonium nitrate.
December 15 – The Islamic Military Counter Terrorism Coalition is formed in order to fight terrorism.
September 30 – Russia begins air strikes against ISIL and anti-government forces in Syria, in support of the Syrian government.

May 11–12 – Version O of Les Femmes d'Alger by Pablo Picasso sells for US$179.3 million at Christie's auction in New York, while the sculpture L'Homme au doigt by Alberto Giacometti sells for US$141.3 million, setting a new world record for a painting and for a sculpture, respectively.

June 25–26 – ISIL claim responsibility for three attacks around the world during Ramadan: Kobanî massacre: ISIL fighters detonate three car bombs, enter Kobanî, Syria, and open fire at civilians, killing more than 220 people. Sousse attacks: 22-year-old Seifeddine Rezgui opens fire at a tourist resort at Port El Kantaoui, Tunisia, killing 38 people.
June 12 – A gunman claiming allegiance to the Islamic State opens fire at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, killing 49 people and injuring 53 others.

September 28 International investigators conclude that Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down by a Buk missile that came from an area controlled by pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. Global CO2 levels exceed 400 ppm at the time of year normally associated with minimum levels.
Andrei Karlov, the Russian ambassador to Turkey, is assassinated by an off-duty Turkish police officer at an art exhibition in Ankara.

October 7 – Three events that will play a significant role in the United States presidential election all take place on the same afternoon: U.S. intelligence agencies publicly accuse the Russian government of using computer hacking to interfere with the U.S. election process; The Washington Post releases a videotape showing candidate Donald Trump privately bragging about sexual improprieties; WikiLeaks releases thousands of private emails from inside the political campaign of candidate Hillary Clinton.

July 12 – The Philippines wins the arbitration case they filed at the Permanent Court of Arbitration regarding the legality of China's "nine-dash line" claim over the South China Sea under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
June 22 – The African and Caribbean War Memorial unveiled in Brixton, London.

October 1 – 60 people are killed and 867 more injured when Stephen Paddock opens fire on a crowd in Las Vegas, surpassing the Orlando nightclub shooting as the deadliest mass shooting perpetrated by a lone gunman in U.S. history.
May 9–13 – The Eurovision Song Contest takes place in Kyiv, Ukraine, and is won by Portuguese entrant Salvador Sobral with the song "Amar Pelos Dois".
October 12 – The United States announces its decision to withdraw from UNESCO, and is immediately followed by Israel.

November 22 – The International Court of Justice finds Ratko Mladić guilty of genocide committed in Srebrenica during the 1990s Bosnian War, the worst massacre in Europe since World War II. He is sentenced to life in prison.
September 2 – A fire breaks out in the National Museum of Brazil in Rio de Janeiro, destroying more than 90 percent of its archive of 20 million items.
May 27 – The first round of voting of the Colombian presidential election is held.
Foreign journalists report that tunnels in the Punggye-ri nuclear test site have been destroyed by the North Korean government in a move to reduce regional tensions.
April 11 – 257 people are killed after an Ilyushin Il-76 belonging to the Algerian Air Force crashes near Algiers.
June 1 – Giuseppe Conte becomes the new Prime Minister of Italy, leading a cabinet described as the "first modern populist government in Western Europe".

September 23 One of the largest and oldest travel firms, Thomas Cook, goes bankrupt as last-minute rescue negotiations fail, stranding 600,000 tourists worldwide. Russia formally adopts the Paris climate agreement.

August 25 – Beirut drone crash: According to Lebanese officials, two Israeli drones attack Beirut, Lebanon. One crashed into the roof of the Hezbollah Media Center, about 45 minutes before the second exploded in the air and damaged the building.

July 3 – Tajoura migrant center airstrike: An airstrike by Field Marshal Khalifa Haftar's Libyan National Army hits the Tajoura Detention Center outside Tripoli, Libya, while hundreds of people are inside the facility, killing at least 53 of them and injuring 130 others.
February 26–27 – The Indian Air Force launches airstrikes on purported militant camps in Balakot, Pakistan. It precedes a series of events that lead to the India–Pakistan standoff.
December 11 – The World Trade Organization is left unable to intervene in trade disputes after the U.S. blocks the appointment of new panel members.

March 9 COVID-19 pandemic: Italy becomes the first country to implement a nationwide quarantine in response to the COVID-19 outbreak. International share prices fall sharply in response to a Russo-Saudi oil price war and the impact of COVID-19.
COVID-19 pandemic: The total number of recovered COVID-19 patients reaches 1 million worldwide, according to data from The Johns Hopkins University.
A fast radio burst is detected from the Magnetar SGR +2154, the first ever detected inside the Milky Way, and the first to be linked to a known source.
October 22 – The Geneva Consensus Declaration on Promoting Women's Health and Strengthening the Family is signed by government representatives from 34 countries.
COVID-19 pandemic: Sinovac's vaccine reached a rate of 91.25% efficacy in trials in Turkey.
A near-total ban on abortion comes into effect in Poland.
May 20 – Following international pressure, and nearly 250 deaths, Israel agrees to a ceasefire deal to end the conflict with Gaza militants, effective the next day at 2:00 am local time.
October 23 – Colombia's most wanted drug lord, Dario Antonio Úsuga, whose Gulf Clan controls many smuggling routes into the US and other countries, is captured by Colombia's armed forces.
Kosovo officially establishes diplomatic ties with Israel and announces plans to open an embassy in Jerusalem.
September 19 – The Russian legislative election is held, with the United Russia party winning nearly 50% of the vote.

October 25 – Rishi Sunak becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, following the resignation of Liz Truss the previous week resulting in a 50-day tenure, making him the first person of colour to become the prime minister.
The Nord Stream pipeline sabotage occurs by an unknown perpetrator off the coast of Bornholm, Denmark with explosions on two pipelines leaving them inoperable.

April 8 Russian invasion of Ukraine: Russia is condemned by world leaders following a missile attack on Kramatorsk train station, which kills 59 civilians trying to evacuate, including seven children. Global food prices increase to their highest level since the UN's Food Price Index began in, with commodities such as wheat rising by nearly 20% as a result of the Ukraine crisis.

Prime Minister of Sri Lanka Mahinda Rajapaksa resigns as a result of massive protests against his government across the country. He is succeeded by Ranil Wickremesinghe as prime minister three days later.
Tropical Storm Ana kills 115 people in Madagascar, Malawi and Mozambique, days after a series of floods killed 11 people in Madagascar.
April 5 – Clashes between Palestinians and the Israeli police happen at Al-Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.
Scientists report the creation of the first synthetic human embryo from stem cells, without the need for sperm or egg cells.

The European Central Bank and Bank of England raise their interest rates by 0.5 percentage points to combat inflation, one day after the US Federal Reserve raises its federal funds rate by 0.25 percentage points.

January 1 – Croatia adopts the euro and joins the Schengen Area, becoming the 20th member state of the Eurozone and the 27th member of the Schengen Area. This is the first enlargement of the Eurozone since Lithuania's entry in, and the first enlargement of the Schengen Area since Liechtenstein's entry in.
Kivu conflict: Angola announces the deployment of troops to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, following the failure of a ceasefire between government forces and M23 rebels in North Kivu.

November 30 Icelandic parliamentary election: Opposition party Social Democratic Alliance wins 15 seats in the Althing, with the incumbent Independence Party winning 14 seats. However, no party achieved a majority.
March 7 – As the final Nordic country to join the alliance, Sweden officially joins NATO, becoming its 32nd member after Finland a year earlier.
March 25 – The UN Security Council passes a resolution calling for an "immediate ceasefire" in the Gaza war and demanding the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages.
February 14 – Indonesian general election: Prabowo Subianto wins the presidential election, and the Democratic Party of Struggle wins the most votes in the legislative election.
May 6 – Chadian presidential election: Mahamat Déby wins election to a full term as president, succeeding his father Idriss Déby.

January 27 – Global technology shares outside China fall sharply in response to the release of DeepSeek's chatbot, a Chinese competitor to OpenAI's ChatGPT. Chip giant Nvidia loses almost $600 billion of its value, the biggest drop for a single company in U.S. stock market history.
Dhaka Chengdu J-7 crash: An F-7 BGI training aircraft of the Bangladesh Air Force crashes into Milestone College in Uttara, Dhaka, killing 31 people including the pilot.

Honduran general election: Amid allegations of fraud and external interference, National candidate Nasry Asfura narrowly wins the presidency after weeks of delays. The National Party additionally wins a plurality in the National Congress.
January 6 – Indonesia becomes the tenth member to join BRICS.

May 3 Australian federal election: The incumbent Labor Party led by Anthony Albanese wins reelection, increasing their majority. Singaporean general election: The incumbent People's Action Party led by Lawrence Wong wins reelection in a landslide, retaining a supermajority government. Malian protests: Hundreds of demonstrators gather in Bamako, Mali, to protest the government's proposed dissolution of political parties and extension of president Assimi Goïta's mandate by 5 years. The protests mark the first pro-democracy demonstrations in the country since the regime took power in.
November – The Bulgarian presidential election is scheduled to be held.
January 7 – The United States seizes two shadow fleet tankers, including one under a Russian flag, in the United States oil blockade during Operation Southern Spear.
September 13 – The Swedish general election is scheduled to be held.
June 7 – The Armenian parliamentary election is scheduled to be held.
June 11–July 19 – The FIFA World Cup is scheduled to be held in Canada, Mexico, and the United States.
In Chalcolithic Europe, the two circles of bluestones that form the inner part of Stonehenge are erected.
– – The First Intermediate Period of Egypt, a period of decline in Egyptian central power.
Epic poetry is written in the Sumerian language, including the Epic of Gilgamesh.
Shahr-e Sukhteh, "The Burnt City" in Persia, is abandoned.
– The beginning of the Middle Kerma culture in Upper Nubia.
– : Reign of Netjerkare Siptah, last pharaoh of the Sixth Dynasty of Egypt, who will later give rise to the legendary figure of Nitocris.
: Austronesians reach the Batanes Islands of the Philippine Archipelago as part of the Austronesian Expansion.
: Possible date for the death of Pharaoh Pepi II Neferkare of the Sixth Dynasty of Egypt, the longest reigning monarch of history with 94 years on the throne.
: Gudea, ruler of Lagash, starts to reign.
4.2-kiloyear event: A severe aridification event that probably lasted the entire and caused the collapse of several Old World civilizations.
: A Guti army swept down from the Zagros Mountains and defeated the demoralized Akkadian army. They took Agade, the capital of Akkad, and destroyed it thoroughly.
: Unetice culture emerges in the modern day Czech Republic.
– : (short chronology) Sargon of Akkad's conquest of Mesopotamia.
: Canal Bahr Yusuf (current name) is created when the waterway from the Nile to the natural lake (now Lake Moeris) is widened and deepened to create a canal.
– : Stela of Naram-Sin, probably from Sippar, discovered in Susa (modern Shush, Iran), is made. It is now in Musée du Louvre, Paris.
–There is archaeological evidence that the site of Assur was occupied at around this time.
: Lugal-Zage-Si of Umma conquers Gu-Edin and unites Sumer as a single kingdom.
–2279 : Semitic chieftain Sargon of Akkad's conquest of Sumer and Mesopotamia.
: Sixth Dynasty of Egypt starts (other date is ).
–2000 : large painted jar with birds in the border made in the Indus River Valley civilization and is now at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
: The sculpture Khafre Enthroned is made.
2900–2334 : Mesopotamian wars of the Early Dynastic period.

: By this time, kings in Sumer have ceased to be automatically high priests of the city deity. (Roux 1980) Infiltration and conquest of Mesopotamia by ancient Semitic-speaking peoples begins. (1968 RD Almanac).
Earliest signs of Corded Ware culture from the Caucasus. (Encyc. Americana).
The southeastern Iberian peninsula is settled from the Mediterranean, by people using Prehistoric Egyptian-style pottery. (Encyc. Americana).
–2493 : Reign of Khafre. the Pyramid of Khafre is built, along with the Great Sphinx of Giza, a monumental sculpture of a pharaoh (either Khafre or Khufu) with a lion's body.
– : Reign of Khufu, second pharaoh of the Fourth Dynasty. The height of the Old Kingdom under the reigns of Khufu, Khafre and Menkaure.
Reigns of Menkaure and Shepseskaf.
–2400 : Early Minoan I period in Crete.
–2485 : Reign of A'annepada, king of Ur.
Earliest records of oil wrestling from Babylonia and Egypt.
Supposed reign of the semi-legendary Sumerian king Gilgamesh.

: End of the Early Dynastic I Period, and the beginning of the Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia. Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
End of the Early Dynastic I Period, and the beginning of the Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
– 2650 : Second Dynasty wars in Ancient Egypt.
: Estimated ending of the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in the region of modern-day Romania, Moldova, and southwestern Ukraine.
– : Seated Harp Player, from Keros, Cyclades, is made. It is now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
– 2400 : Sumerian pictographs evolve into phonograms.

: Suggested date for an asteroid or comet impact occurring between Africa and Antarctica, around the time of a lunar eclipse on May 10, based on an analysis of flood stories. Possibly causing the Burckle crater and Fenambosy Chevron.
– 2334 : Mesopotamian wars of the Early Dynastic period.
: Saqqara Tomb A construction started.
: Estimated germination of the Prometheus Tree, previously thought to be the world's oldest living organism until it was cut down in 1964.
3300 – 2600 : Early Harappan period continues in the Indus Valley.
: Early agriculture in North Africa.
: Stonehenge begins to be built. In its first version, it consists of a circular ditch and bank, with 56 wooden posts.
: Camels are domesticated in Egypt.
: There is an intense phase of burial at Duma na nGiall on the Hill of Tara, the ancient seat of the High King of Ireland.
– 2600 : Skara Brae, Orkney islands is inhabited.
?: The Anu Ziggurat and White Temple are built in Uruk.
?: Early Dynastic period starts in Ancient Egypt.
: Polo (Meitei: Sagol Kangjei) was first played in Manipur state.
?: First stage in the construction of Stonehenge.
?: Beginning of the reign of Narmer, first pharaoh to unify Ancient Egypt and founder of the 1st Dynasty.
?: Neolithic people in Ireland build the 250,000-ton (230,000-tonne) Newgrange solar-oriented passage tomb.
– ?: Reign of King Double Falcon of Lower Egypt. There is a strong possibility that he appears on the Palermo stone, although half his name is chipped away.
– : Reign of Scorpion II in Upper Egypt..
?: Malta: Construction of the Ħaġar Qim megalithic temples, featuring both solar and lunar alignments. "Tarxien period" of megalithic temple construction reaches its apex.
Sahara changes from a habitable region into a barren desert.
: The Red Temple, the first phase of the Monte d'Accoddi sanctuary in Northwest Sardinia, is built.
Ancient Egypt begins using clay, bone and ivory tags to label boxes, possibly an example of proto-writing.

-3000 : Evidence of proto-Thracians or proto-Dacians in the prehistoric period; Proto-Dacian or proto-Thracian people developed from a mixture of indigenous peoples and Indo-Europeans from the time of Proto-Indo-European expansion in the Early Bronze Age.
: to 3000 : Face of a woman, from Uruk (modern Warka, Iraq) is made; it is now in the Iraq Museum, Baghdad (stolen and recovered in 2003).
: The Sumerians develop a logographic script, cuneiform.
: The Eruption of Mount Isarog in the Philippines.
: The first monument of which there is still a trace (Duma na nGiall) is built on the Hill of Tara, the ancient seat of the High King of Ireland.
The Sahara desert starts to form from semi-arid savannah, through desertification.
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
: The Sumerians develop a logographic script, cuneiform.
: Pictographic proto-writing starts developing towards writing proper in Sumer, thus starting what is technically considered history.
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
The Sahara desert starts to form from semi-arid savannah, through desertification.
: The oldest estimated germination of Alerce Milenario with more conservative dates of only ‘c.1653 ’.
Beginning of the construction of the megalithic Ggantija temple complex in Malta.
Mnajdra solar temple complex, Malta.
In Egypt, evidence found of mummification around this time at a cemetery in Nekhen.
Colombia, first rupestrian art at Chiribiquete.
Civilization in Sumer (Uruk period).
Indus Valley civilisation in South Asia.
In the south of England, a rapid expansion of monument building occurred around.
Settlement of the River area of Barbuda (c. ), formation of sand dunes on Palmetto Point.
In the city of Uruk, southern Mesopotamia, groups of tokens representing commercial transactions begin to be enclosed in hollow clay balls and kept in archives.
The Maykop culture, a major Bronze Age archaeological culture in the Western Caucasus region of Southern Russia, began around.
– the first year of the Hebrew calendar.
–2700 – Dolmen of Dombate [gl].
Ubaid period came to an abrupt end in eastern Arabia and the Oman peninsula at.
– Disintegration of the Proto-Semitic language.
An earthquake near a Neolithic culture at Sotira in Cyprus destroys much of the local infrastructure.
The Sweet Track, an ancient causeway also in the Somerset Levels, the oldest timber trackway discovered in Northern Europe, is built in or ; tree-ring dating enabled very precise dating.
The Post Track, an ancient causeway in the Somerset Levels, England, is built, c.. It is one of the oldest engineered roads discovered in Northern Europe.
Clay pots and vats discovered at a sprawling cave system in southern Armenia near the border with Iran shows signs of an organized effort to press and distill grapes.
Approximate time of the construction of the Merheleva Ridge complex.
, more than 100 dwellings surrounding a community center, a cemetery and a kiln are built in Jiangzhai, near modern Xi'an, China.
Metallurgy during the Copper Age in Europe.
Megalithic monuments are constructed in Brittany, Portugal, central and southern France, Corsica and Great Britain.
